parts: This reality show chronicles the lives of several celebrities such as Paul DelVecchio and professional wrestler Nicole Polizzi. It is named after the location where it was set every other season.
This other show has a long list of 13 seasons and mainly follows three sisters whose names all start with K, along with their extensive and dramatic family.

One of Kim Kardashian’s most famously publicized events was when this happened to her during Paris Fashion Week of 2016. As a result of it, production of Keeping Up with the Kardashians was postponed for three weeks.
Name this classic impossible construction from the ancient Greeks that involved dividing an angle into a namesake number of parts.
Angle trisection can be done using a trisectrix named for this Scottish mathematician. He also names a special case of a Taylor series centered at x=0.

Another example of a trisectrix is the Tschirnhausen cubic, which was studied by its namesake, L'Hôpital, and this man. This man's namesake numbers are described by the formula “one over the quantity n plus one close quantity times the quantity two n choose n” and begin 1, 1, 2, 5, 14.
Priscus was the first king of Rome from this civilization. These inhabitants of Tuscany referred to themselves as Rasenna.
When Priscus first entered Rome, his wife Tanaquil prophesied his greatness after one of these animals removed his cap and put it back on his head.
Priscus was succeeded as king by this man, who conducted the first Roman census. He was murdered on the orders of Tarquinius Superbus, after which his daughter intentionally drove over his dead body.

answers: “The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber”
parts: Name this short story whose titular subject is killed by his wife Margot.
The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber was written by this author, better known for novels like For Whom the Bell Tolls.
Margot accidentally shoots Francis when he is about to be gored by one of these animals. A David Mamet play is titled for an “American” one of them.
Name this emperor of Ethiopia, worshipped as a messiah in Rastafarianism.
The aforementioned chemical weapons were used by this country, which conquered Ethiopia in 1935. It was led at the time by Benito Mussolini.
This longest-serving head of the Derg led Ethiopia during the Ogaden War and the 1983-85 famine. He was forced out of power shortly before Eritrean independence.
Name this most abundant organic compound on Earth, which makes up most of a plant's cell wall.
This other compound makes up most of bacterial cell walls. Penicillin inhibits the formation of this compound, thereby acting as an antibiotic.
This antimicrobial enzyme, which is naturally found in human tears and sweat, catalyzes the cleavage of bonds within peptidoglycan in bacterial cell walls, thus weakening them.
Name this German-born American philosopher who compared the roots of Stalinism and Nazism in The Origins of Totalitarianism.

In this work by Arendt, the central figure is said to have relied on made up cliches and stock phrases and claimed that the central figure had to rely on family connections to get a job with a vacuum cleaner company.
In Eichmann In Jerusalem, Arendt claimed that Eichmann had exhibited the banal form of this concept, which she contrasted with the radical kind.

answers: Joanna the Mad (or Joanna of Castile; or Joanna of Aragon) <Sivakumar>
parts: In this country, the death of Fyodor I, who reportedly suffered from mental retardation, resulted in the Time of Troubles.
This king was insane for the last eight years of his life, during which Spencer Perceval was assassinated and the British helped win the Napoleonic Wars.
Antoine de Lalaing chronicled this ruler’s journey from Burgundy to be recognized as heiress of Castile. She was later declared mentally unfit to rule by her father Ferdinand II.
Name this phenomenon caused by imperfect lenses, where optical images are distorted. One type of this phenomenon is called “chromatic.”

This type of aberration occurs when light at the edge of a lens refracts more strongly than light near the center. This adjective also describes a type of three-dimensional coordinate system using rho, phi, and theta.
Aberrations can be described by these polynomials that are orthogonal on the unit circle. These polynomials can be applied in ENZ theory.
Name this poem which describes the narrator’s father “Stooping in rhythm through potato drills” while performing the titular action.
“Digging” was written by this Irish poet who won the 1995 Nobel Prize in Literature. A young boy loses his fascination for frogs in this man’s “Death of a Naturalist.”
Like Heaney, this British author created a notable translation of Beowulf. He also wrote The Hobbit and the Lord of the Rings series.
This composer left the symphonic poem Popol Vuh unfinished at his death. He celebrated his native country in his Danzas Argentinas but is better known for the ballet Estancia.
Ginastera wrote twelve “American” pieces of this type for solo piano. J.S. Bach composed 48 fugues and 48 of these pieces for The Well-Tempered Clavier.
This Brazilian composer was inspired by his country’s street music to write 14 “Choros,” but is better known for his Bachianas Brasileiras.

answers: Lamanites [or descendants of Laman, or clear knowledge equivalents] <Mathew>
parts: Name this founder of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
This Mormon scripture includes sections on Moses and Abraham, a part of the Bible according to Joseph Smith, and “The Articles of Faith.”
This group of people, one of the Mormon nations, destroyed the Nephites in America. They descend from Lehi and have dark skin.
Name this notoriously heavy president who succeeded Theodore Roosevelt.
Taft described this alliterative diplomatic policy as substituting the titular objects for bullets. It aimed to increase US influence in several countries by establishing loan systems.
Early in his administration, Taft passed this tariff named for two Republican senators. It split Republicans into Progressive and Old Guard factions, leading to their loss in the elections of 1810.
This Italian artist moved to London after her father Orazio became a court painter of Charles I. She is best known for her painting Judith Beheading Holofernes.

While in England, this man painted the ceiling of Inigo Jones’s Banqueting House at Whitehall. This artist depicted himself and his first wife under a honeysuckle bower and also painted The Three Graces.
This painter’s portrait of Philip II helped Philip win the hand of Mary I. A brown dog and a servant rummaging through a chest appear in the background of his Venus of Urbino.
Name this Renaissance humanist known for his collection Il Canzoniere.
Petrarch is most famous for introducing a namesake type of this poetic form. He dedicated several of these works to a woman called Laura.
This poet of “Whoso List to Hunt” and “They Flee from Me” was responsible for popularizing the sonnet in England.

answers: cyclohexene (do not accept hexane or hexyne)
parts: Name this 4+2 cycloaddition of a diene and a dienophile.
The Diels-Alder reaction forms a cyclic version of this molecule, with formula C6H10.
Cyclohexene can be cleaved to form adipic acid using hydrogen peroxide and this element as a catalyst. This metal is found along with oxygen and calcium in scheelite.
The mate of Typhon, this half-woman and half-snake creature is known as the mother of all monsters. Her most famous offspring include Cerberus and the Nemean Lion.
This creature with the head of a human and the body of a lion asks Oedipus a famous riddle outside of Thebes. A statue of this creature also exists near the Great Pyramids of Giza.

Images of these creatures, which have the head of a human, the body of a bull or a lion, and the wings of a bird were often engraved in clay tablets and buried under the threshold of doors to protect homes in Assyrian culture. They are associated with the gods Papsukkal and Išum.
Name this field of economics that focuses on conflict and cooperation. It is often represented by the prisoner’s dilemma.

In the prisoner’s dilemma, there is only one of these points, which is reached when both prisoners defect. These points are reached when neither player can improve their position with unilateral changes to strategy.
Game theory is often applied to these markets that often have kinked demand curves. These market’s durability was demonstrated by Hotelling’s linear city model.
Diaghilev’s most controversial ballet was this work, which depicts a young girl dancing herself to death. It caused riots at its 1913 premiere.
Diaghilev frequently worked with this choreographer of Till Eulenspiegel’s Merry Pranks. In one of his ballets, he notoriously mimed an obscene gesture with the scarf of a nymph.
This artist designed the set of Le Boutique Fantastique for a performance by Diaghilev. Like Monet, this artist painted a view of Charing Cross Bridge.
Name this author, who wrote about the painter Elaine Risley in Cat’s Eye.
In Atwood’s 2005 novella The Penelopiad, the title character reflects on events from this Homer play which followed the Iliad.
This other Canadian female author is known for short stories like “Dance of the Happy Shades” and “The Moons of Jupiter”.
